title: [release 0.12.0] non-Go code set up signal handler without SA_ONSTACK flag when adding account in wallet
body:
### Description

1. install app https://ci.infra.status.im/job/status-desktop/job/release/job/release%252F0.12.x/4/
2. enable biometrics
3. open wallet
4. click Add account and confirm action with fingerprint

```
ERR 2023-05-10 10:41:32.171+03:00 sm_cannot resolve current state            topics="app-controller" tid=430094 file=module.nim:136
signal 16 received but handler not on signal stack
fatal error: non-Go code set up signal handler without SA_ONSTACK flag

SIGABRT: Abnormal termination.
```

per Sale this should be fixed by switching to Go-1.20.4, or commit ffa200f32dece7472e2d9a9584e172804c991d05

@iurimatias @alaibe please make the adjustments needed
This commit is in the release, so there is something else going on
@alexjba does this ring a bell? (esp. the part with `fatal error: non-Go code set up signal handler without SA_ONSTACK flag`)

to give some context, the signal is not being raised by the keycard library or by the pcsc library. Signal 16 (on darwin) is used internally by the go runtime as a preemption signal, to switch the active routine. Because of a bug specific to aarch64 the stack pointer could end up in a area outside the expected range, causing this fatal error.

The issue has been fixed in go 1.20.4 and @saledjenic's local build works fine, so the next step would be to find out what is the difference between what is being built locally and CI's build

I guess we need to revisit this: https://github.com/status-im/status-desktop/blob/a57c0b414bd52b39ce6e0060280ba5e3cd444f4a/src/nim_status_client.nim#LL91C20-L91C20

Adding `SA_ONSTACK` might fix the issue as `go` docs says:
```
If the non-Go code installs any signal handlers, it must use the SA_ONSTACK flag with sigaction. Failing to do so is likely to cause the program to crash if the signal is received. Go programs routinely run with a limited stack, and therefore set up an alternate signal stack.
```

Signal 16 seems to be `{16, "SIGURG", "urgent I/O condition"}` and might signal a bug in the app, but I don't think it should crash the app.

```
SIGURG (Urgent I/O condition)
          This signal is generated when an ``urgent condition'' exists on a
          socket.  In practice this means when [tcp(4)](https://man.netbsd.org/tcp.4) out-of-band data has
          arrived.  The default action is to do nothing.  The number for
          SIGURG is 16.
```
